answer.para: T^{-1}(2) is the set of all those (x,y) in \RNr[2] on the line 2x+y=2, while T^{-1}(-2) is the set of all those (x,y) in \RNr[2] on the line 2x+y=-2. Both lines are perpendicular to the vector (2,1). So they are parallel.

problem.para: What is the preimage of a point \Vect{z} in \RNr[3] if \Vect{z} does not belong to H?
Does every \Vect{y} in \RNr[2] have a nonempty preimage under R?

solution.para: To answer this question, recall that every rotation is invertible: If R rotates through the angle \theta about the origin, the inverse of R is the rotation S which rotates through the the angle -\theta.
Therefore the preimage of \Vect{y} under R is given by R^{-1}(\Vect{y}) = S(\Vect{y}). Therefore R^{-1}(\Vect{y}) consists of a single point. In particular it is not empty.

problem.para: How many points can there be in the preimage of \Vect{y}?

solution.para: There is exactly one point in the preimage of \Vect{y} under R, namely the point R^{-1}(\Vect{y}).
